title: How many Euros do I get for the pound? Holidaymakers warned as pound slumps
text:
How many Euros do I get for the pound? Holidaymakers warned as pound slumps 14:33, 11 Oct 2016 Since the Brexit vote sterling has been steadily falling - meaning bad news for those planning a winter getaway Share Get daily news by email Euro, dollar and pound sterling notes are seen beside a UK passport 
Holidaymakers planning a cheap winter getaway to Europe will be sad to learn that the majority of UK airports are now exchanging less than one euro to the pound. 
The continued fall in sterling’s value since Brexit means that the average rate available at 17 airport bureaux de change is now just 99 euro cents to the pound. 
At Newcastle Airport the rate was a little better at €1.08 on Tuesday but long gone are the days of the early noughties when a pound bought €1.70. 
The worst exchange rate is currently 88 euro cents at Moneycorp at Southampton airport. 
And depressingly, the dollar – which once gave you double the pound – now averages at about $1.08. 
The survey of airport bureau de change currency rates was carried out by travel money firm FairFX on Monday morning. Read More Sangria at the ready as Ryanair announces new flights from Newcastle Airport 
FairFX said the figures mean airport providers are charging travellers as much as 26% commission for the convenience of buying travel money at the last minute. 
The firm’s chief executive, Ian Strafford-Taylor, said many travellers would be shocked by the poor rates on offer. Read More North East welcomes Heathrow Airport plans to increase domestic flights 
“Currency firms operating in airports are known to offer the worst exchange rates down to taking big profit margins and today are shockingly offering holidaymakers below one euro to the pound,” he said. 
“Unfortunately, if the pound falls even further, rates as poor as this could be seen at airport providers up and down the country - taking advantage of their captive audience of holidaymakers and business travellers.” 
On Tuesday, the pound fell to its weakest level since the financial crisis broke out as worries persist over UK’s economic prospects outside the EU . 
The currency has been this year’s worst performer among 32 major currencies tracked by Bloomberg.
